author: afr.com
title: Apple readies first Australia bonds issue
text:
Apple is rated AA+ by Standard & Poor's and Aa1 by Moody's. David Paul Morris by Jonathan Shapiro John McDuling Global technology giant Apple Inc is set to enter the Australian corporate bond market.
The world's largest company has appointed three banks – Commonwealth Bank, Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs – to arrange a series of investor calls to update local bond managers on the "Apple credit" ahead of a possible debut bond issue.
"It's terrific that global champions are recognising that they get funding diversification in the Australian bond market," said Aberdeen Asset Management's head of Asia Pacific credit research John Manning.
"Apple should offer good diversification for local investors but I am sure there will be interest through the Asia Pacific region."
The company's treasury team, which is based in Nevada, is understood to have kept a close eye on developments in the Australian bond market as it seeks to diversify its multi-billion dollar debt book. The company has raised funds in yen, Swiss francs and euros in addition to its main funding currency, US dollars.
The company was said to be encouraged by a recent $700 million bond issue in the Australian market by global brewer SABMiller, giving it comfort it can diversify funding through an Australian bond issue,
Apple has more than $US200 billion in cash sitting on its balance sheet, much of it stored offshore. But due to US government taxation rules it is unable to repatriate this cash. So, it borrows money, often in foreign currencies, and uses the proceeds to buy back stock and pay its shareholders a dividend.
In April, the company said it would return $US 200 billion to shareholders through buybacks and dividends over the next two years. CEO Tim Cook previously faced pressure from activist investor Carl Icahn to return more of Apple's enormous cash hoard to shareholders.
 ​Apple has also invested a portion of its cash pile into Australian dollars and is understood to be one of the largest buyers of Australian bank commercial paper sold in the US.
Apple is rated AA+ by Standard & Poor's and Aa1 by Moody's - which is two notches higher than the Commonwealth Bank. That means the bonds won't come cheap. Apple's 5-year US bonds currently pay a yield of 2.13 per cent or around 50 percentage points above the US government bond rate. That is the identical rate and spread to CBA's US bonds.
